Very gassy stout dark pour tan head in colour aromas coffee grassy fruit dark chocolate the flavours caramel roasted coffee dark chocolate grassy notes dark malts molasses brown sugar very rich stout the finish good body tastes rewarding best of them rich malts roasted coffee bitter finish so good

From a 750ml bomber, purchased at Central City Liquor Store in Surrey. Almost black, with prodigious orange-brown head, quickly collapsing, but with good lacing. Sweet fruits and malts on the nose. In the mouth it is a somewhat sweet and very smooth and subtle rendition of one of my favorite themes in beer, which is to say "stout".

Yes, there are flavors of chocolate, vanilla, caramel and fruit to be found here, and the hops are well hidden, but at the moment I dont want to be too analytical. I just want to savor!
CBC 2013. Pours pitch black with a small tanned head. Aroma is malty coffee some vanilla fruity nicely roasted. Flavor is ashy dry thin body roasted slightly sweet fruity.

Bottle at Hotel Sofia. Pours next to black with a creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, some ash and caramel. Flavor is sweet and malty with some dark berries, rotated grains and coffee. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle, 75cl. It pours a next to black body, topped by a dense, finger-thick light tan head. The aroma is roasted, with a touch of dark berries. Roasted malts, some dark chocolate and coffee too. Its full-bodied and pleasantly carbonated, with flavors of roasted malts, some berry hints, dark chocolate and a touch of warming alcohol. Long, roasted, chocolatey finish. Most definitely a nice one, like so many others from Stillwater. 130814

Pours almost black with a light tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, earthy hops. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter with a long roasted, fruity and chocolate finish., Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

750ml bottle. Pours a deep black color with a one finger beige head that falls quickly with little lacing. Smells of roasted coffee, some cocoa and dates. Taste is dark fruit malt, cherries followed by a light coffee malt. Medium earthy bitterness with dark cherry fruitiness throughout. Finishes is dry, and slightly roasty , with some liquorice. Medium body and moderate carbonation, very smooth and creamy.

750 ml bottle. Gusher - what a waste. Negative points. Pours black with huge head (of course). Aromas of dark chocolate, heavily roasted malts and shoe polish. Somewhat sweet and dry. Flavors of dark milk chocolate, sweet coffee, and roasted malts.

No bottling information.

Taste: Fruit notes are abundant throughout of apple cider and banana with a cocoa backing and a touch of roast. The flavor is a little watery during the mid thought light coffee aromas overlie it. This needs a bit more malt beef to it and it would be about perfect.
Palate: A bit thin for the style, a touch watery. Carbonation is low.
Overall: This is pretty darn good, but its missing body and needs a bit more carbonation. This is hinting at perfect, but is missing on some key marks.
Dark black with giant tan head. Sweet and bubbly with a hint of chocolate. Solid.
This was poured from a keg at El Bait shop in Des Moines. Black pour with thin white head. A little watery but good coffee and malty flavor
Cloudy dark brown small brown head. Roasted malts, caramel coffee, flavor is roasted malts licorice caramel coffee

Dunkelbraun, trüb mit Bergen aus Schaum. Sehr hefige Nase mit Kakao- u. Röstmalzaromen. Tap at baitshop... pitch black thick pour..smoky taste and aroma.. bitter finish..i dig it

Bottle, shared with Parksy and Smitty. Hearty near-black pour infused with lively carbonation requiring a staged pour. Aroma is burnt malts and dark fruits in equal proportion, with a rustic yeasty character. The palate is unmistakably heavy and full-bodied, but with lots of carbo. Not sure how I feel about the carbo-- I like my stouts (whether sweet or foreign or impy) to have a silky rich mouthfeel, and the carbo interferes with this. The flavours are spot on though-- sweet dark fruits with chocolate and bready yeast, some sweet light smoke. Really lovely flavours, very Belgian in character.

text: From 75 cl bottle shared at home. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted grain. Flavors of chocolate, coffee and a hint of toffee. Bitter, roasted finish.

750ml bottle pours almost black in color with a finger of light brown head that settles to leave a few spots of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is roasted grains and dark chocolate with hints of coffee.  Taste is a chocolate malty sweetness with a roasted grain bitterness.  Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.  Well done.

Very dark brown pour, sizeable tan head. Chicory and dark fruits on the nose. Slightly tinny/mineral-laden flavor  like someone added seltzer water to what I thought this was going to taste like. Love the label, but this brew isnt my favorite  these farmhouse ales are better when lighter, in my book. This particular bottle seemed to have far too much carbonation - made it difficult to drink - had to sip it like champagne.

Black beer with an off-white head. Aromas of dark chocolate and bourbon. Tastes of dark licorice, some watery coffee, charred wheat, and some caramel. Tap @ CBC 2013. The pours black with a small head. The nose is soured roasted malt. Light cocoa and bitter chocolate. The taste is damson, soured fruits, chocolate. Some wild yeast. Raspberry tart. Medium body, fine carbonation. Overall, solid.

200ml shared with Skinnyviking, from tap at Mikkeller & Friends. Jet black body, fawn-coloured head. Dotted spots to the glassware. Sweet malts and herbal hops to the nose. Flavoured with dark fruits, anise and vanilla sweetness. Roasted bittersweet tail. Medium to full bodied. Another good one from the brewery (Copenhagen, 22.05.2013).

Draft at the Birch.  A big, muddy, dark brown beer with a big rollicking head.  This has a nice sweet essence, drinking almost like a cola ... chocolate, sugar, but light and drinkable.  Interesting and good.  (#5030, 5/25/2013)

A steady, soft pour into my Lost Abbey Teku glass produces a three finger, multi-bubble-size layered, nicely brown head that slowly rizes above the rim of my glass before . The beer is a concentrated brown, not quite black color that shows an opaque, though perhaps slightly amber tinged, brown hue when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of deeply charred prunes, dusty dark cocoa, slightly musty concentrated cold coffee, and acidic, roasted malt. The nose isnt really all that funky (in a Saison sort of way), but instead focuses more on the dark malt / grain with supporting fruit notes.  As the beer warms up a bit a slightly earthy, deeply toasty, whole grain character starts to come out in the aroma; this helps to temper the roasted grain character.  There is a hint of smoky character to the nose that seems mostly contributed by the roasted grain character.

Expressively carbonated, the beer foams up quite a bit as it hits the mouth.  There is a rich, dark chocolate and cold espresso like dark grain character here that lingers on in the finish with a burnt, though smooth, edge.  My second sip has me noticing a subtle, underlying fruitiness that tastes of burned prunes and raisins. Deeply toasted, brown-whole-grain flavors intermingle with the deeply roasted notes.  The body is quite light compared to something like a Stout, though it isnt as bone thin as a my favorite type of pale Saisons; here though the beer needs a touch of body to counteract the roast malt character, and this one has a little something extra to the texture.  This slight viscous character certainly doesnt balance the dominant roast character though, so you need to be in the mood for a deeply roasted beer.  The burnt / roasted character adds a definite bitterness and even some acidity to this beer; this last is also accentuated by the carbonic bite that is in this beer.  There is a touch of smokiness to the finish that is brought out by the roasted character and perhaps a hint of phenolics. Actually the smokiness is a bit more pervasive, though still on the subtler side, with a rich character evocative of umami and salt that adds a certain savory quality to this beer that boosts the perceived body of this brew. This smokiness / savory quality goes a long way towards balancing out this beer as it warms up.

I really wonder what the yeast used was here, the beer is quite dry for a Stout, though not excessively so, and is certainly quite clean for a Saison or Belgianish creation; whatever it is, the beer is fairly cleanly fermented, but definitely dry / light for a beer of this strength. In the end this is quite nice, it really needs to warm up a bit (I initially served it at 50°F / 10°C) before it gets balanced, and actually it starts out a bit too carbonated for the roast and smoke character, but some air and time help with that nicely as well.

These guys make some solid saisons...perhaps they should stick to the style.  Muddy dark mahogany bordering black pour with a 1/2 inch latte head.  Aroma of smoke, Belgian yeast, cocoa, and raisin.  Definitely get the yeast in flavor also accompanied by chocolate and fruit.  Medium mouthfeel.

On draft at the Livermore Saloon. It pours dark brown with a thick brown head. The aroma is over ripe fruit with some earthy root vegetables and hints of coffee and licorice. The flavor is very earthy and roasted with hints of raisins and some soap and pepper (yeast?) The finish is toasty and dry. Not really my thing.
Draft. Bolack beer with a dark tan head. Chocolate and light roast aroma with caramel. Light roast and chocolate flavor with caramel. Medium bodied. light roast and chocolate lingers with caramel.

tuesday night bottle.  pours dark hazy brown with nice beige head and good lacing.  nose is dark fruit, coffe, and chalk.  Tastes quite good with cola, dark chocolate, prunes, earth, grass, and vanilla.  drying on finish and lingering goodness

25.4 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a craggy, dirty tan head.  Nose is prune, hay, licorice and mild smoke.  Medium to full body with a sharp tang.  A touch chalky and metallic but still lively and substantial.  Taste is dark roast, coffee, Belgian yeast, tart blackberries and smoke.
Bottle from whole foods.  Ashy, malts, tobacco... Sharply carbonated for a stout.  Beige head atop

Draft at Taproom 307 with Erica (12.07.2011). Pours black with a pretty big light brown head. Aroma is chalky, malty, roasty. Palate is roastiness and good balance. Pretty thick/heavy mouthfeel, but the beer was still refreshing early on when it was cold. Got a little bland as it went along.

Draft at Pizzeria Paradiso Dupont Circle.  Darkest brown in color with a one finger tan head.  Belgian aroma with dark fruit - berries and vinous notes - along with some chocolate.  Chocolatey fruity flavor, rather vinous, with Belgian yeast and anise.  Smooth mouthfeel with average carbonation level.  A nice American Belgian style ale.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2012 4oz pour at Churchkey is an oily, opaque black with some cloudy white head.  Nose is chalky chocolate, cherries, malty, toasted bread.  Flavor is sweet, malty, chocolate, coffee, pencil lead.  Medium bodied, dry finish.********  Re-rate, sampled at the DC Local Tasting a 750ml bottle pours a watery, opaque black with some creamy off white head.  Nose is standard, lavender, vanilla, malty, nutty.  Flavor is sweet, malty, vanilla, herbs, molasses.  Medium bodied, dry finish.  Might be my favorite Stillwater beer.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2015 Bottle at The Funky 7, Brooklyn. Really cool to try this. Pours dark, cloudy brown with a large, tan head. Aroma holds some dark, roasted malts, cocoa, and hints of dark fruits. Light to medium sweet flavor, plenty of baking cocoa, roast, subtle vanilla. Medium to full bodied with average carbonation. Lightly warming finish, more chocolate, nice dry bitterness, decent roastiness. Very solid beer. Thank you. (August 2011, score: 4.1)Draft at CBC 2012 - Copenhagen. Pours dark brown with a creamy beige cap. Toasted dark bread in the nose, some Belgian candi sugar, light roast, dusty cocoa. Medium sweet flavor with moderate roast continuing, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, light milk chocolate. Medium bodied with average carbonation and creamy texture. Balanced finish, with dark sugars, dark bread, light yeast, more milk chocolate. Very good stuff. (May 2012, score: 3.9)

Pours black with avg tan head and receding lacing.  Aromas of cocoa and some booze.  Taste is sweet, more bitter than expected and quite smooth, almost like a porter.  Overall, this a quite tasty as I am not a big Belgian Strong Ale fan, this one is good.

bottle... dark brown almost black, light tan head, good carbonation, nice looking beer... the nose has lots of Belgian yeast with chocolate and grass not bad... the taste is pretty nice as well, a bit too much yeast though

This beer has been renamed Folklore. Served on cask at Khyber Pass Pub. 

Pours a deep, dark chetnut brown color thats completely opaque with a half finger light beige head that slowly settles into a thin ring. Minimal spots of lacing.

Slightly earthy aroma with some dark malts, faint funky saison yeast, bread and zesty spice. Hints of pepper and clove along with some chocolate and dark fruits.

Medium bodied but on the lighter end with a slightly creamy texture.  Decent balance of dark malt, vinous dark fruit, peppery spice and earthy saison yeast. Lots of sweetness up front with hints of raisin and plum followed by chocolate malt, bready yeast and grass. Slightly medicinal with faint peppery spice. Well balnced and quaffable but theres an odd, lingering, metallic aftertaste. Decent but nothing out of the ordinary.

Bottle This beer rocks! Pours black with a mid-sized, creamy, cappuccino head that never completely disappears. The aromatics are super chocolaty with toasted nuts and a glob of caramel. Full-bodied and silky with tingly carbonation. Sweet, milk chocolaty flavor with a nice note of vanilla and a splash of medium sherry. Finishes smooth, roasty and bittersweet. Bottle courtesy of ygtbsm94. Hoping for a speedy recovery for you, Brad!

Draft at Churchkey. Black pour with a dense beige head. Nose and flavor are marked by creamy vanilla, latte, mocha, cinnamon, nutmeg, milk chocolate, and a tinge of deep plum and vinous notes. Palate is standard for the style. Similar to Allagash Black in many ways. Good, not great.

Bottle, snagged somewhere in Baltimore this summer.  Pours black wih a tan head.  Nose is floral yeastiness, roast, some cherry, sweet dark caramel, alcohol.  Flavor is sweet toffee maltiness up front, then floral yeastiness, sour & sweet cherry.  Very dry.  Velvety mouthfeel.

500ml bottle in a tulip.  Pours black with a thick, lacy, tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, a little smokiness, some fruitiness/spiciness from the yeast, and some light hops to balance it.  A really interesting beer, but it could be thicker and have more of each flavor.  Average texture.  A really good beer.

(bottle) Opaque black body with a thin, receding tan head. Aroma of sweet roasted malt, chocolate, earth, very slight sour notes. Medium and creamy body with a light, carbonated mouthfeel. Flavor of dark chocolate, dark roasted malt, slight sour notes, and earthy, with a dry finish.

(500ml bottle thanks to ryan) dark near black, cloudy pour with dark tan head. Nose of rich chocolate, cream. Taste of chocolate malt, creamy, near fudgey, with a creamy finish and prickly carbonation.

500ml bottle.  Black at first glace, the dark, inky, mahogany colored body supports a small crown of smooth, dark khaki foam.  Settling in as a thin film, the head leaves scant, rounded flares of lacing behind.  Aromas are darkly roasted, showing notes of toasted, bittersweet cacao nibs, singed caramel, burnt barley, and subtle wisps of anise.  Belgian yeast offers a dry, slightly creamy element, hinting also at some dark spice and dark fruit esters.  Flavors are very well balanced (for my palate anyway....might be a bit on the dry/roasty side for most), again based in darkly roasted barley, bittersweet cacao, and burn caramel, but also nicely hopped with earthen tones, and dried out with spicy, fruity Belgian yeast.  The finish is long and roasty.  The palate sports ample body, yet remains fleet of foot due to the significant attenuation and lively, active carbonation.  The flurry of micro-bubbles on the tongue intensifies the spiciness of the yeast.  Overall, I find this to be a damn fine, highly drinkable foreign stout.  Stillwater does a really good job with this Belgian yeast.  Good stuff.

A: The pour is almost black in color with a tall off-white head.

S: Not sure where to start.  Its certainly very roasty and there are lots of dark fruits to this.  Seems to lean heavily toward the prunes, plums, and raisins camp.  There is a mild tartness and a few hints of coffee.  Maybe some oak and chocolate, too.

T: The fruitiness is more pronounced in the flavor.  Prunes and plums really stand out, but there are also some notes of cherries and raisins.  A nice bit of roast, some licorice, and light flavors of pepper and chocolate.

M: Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation.

O: All sorts of different stuff going on here.  I liked it for the most part, though.
bottle - dry chocolate, roasted malts and nutty coffee with a touch of smoke. Cassis and cherry fruits. some grassiness on the finish and a bit soapy. Tasty but odd.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and licorice aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and licorice flavor with hints of caramel. Ha sa roasted malty chocoalte and licorice finish.

Bottle courtesy of beerandblues2 at the 14th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering, 3/19/11. Pours a clear dark brown color with a thin tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of dry roasted malts, chocolate, nutty notes and a bit of banana. The taste is chocolate, roasted malts, tart cherries and some banana. Medium-full bodied. very nice beer.

Bottle. Courtesy of Hopscotch. Pours black with a medium creamy light tan head. The aroma is chocolate, light yeast, dried fruit, hard roasted malt and light smoke. The flavour is malty bitter, light spicy, yeast, dried fruit, chocolate and some roast. Nice one!
At ACBF 2011.  Black colour.  Some dark malts on the aroma.  Tastes a bit unbrewed out.  Not fully attenuated.  Some dryness on finish.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of malt, fruit, bubblegum, Belgian yeast, Belgian chocolate, roasting, and light caramel.  Poured dark brown in color with a small, creamy, dense, brown head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, chocolate, roasting, light smoke, light Belgian yeast, and light coffee.   Medium body.  Lightly dry texture.  Average to slightly lively carbonation.  Malt, roast, slight smoke, Belgian yeast, light coffee, light chocolate finish.  8.4%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Tasted on 7/24/11 from a 500mL bottle at Lush Roscoe.  Pours opaque dark brown with a thick tan head that slowly recedes to nothing more than a very thin collar of lace.  The nose is darkly roasted coffee malt with some dusty dark chocolate, very light smokiness, and an almost cassis-like dark fruit character, but there is also an almost tart aroma that seems out of place as well.  The flavor is just and dark and dusty with the dark chocolate, coffee, and light smoke, along with a very heavy cocoa flavor on the back of the palate.  The body is medium with average, stinging carbonation and a long, heavy, cocoa finish.

500ml bottle from once upon a vine southside. pours a dusky, dark brown with a thick, creamy, light mocha head with great retention and smooth lacing. aroma is damn nice with heavy dark fruit notes of plum, red grape, fig, and date backed by light roast, cocoa powder, spices, and yeast with hints of wood and light smoke. flavor is delicious with an excellent balance of roasted malts, light espresso, and bakers chocolate with dark fruit esters of plum, raisin, and figs with a lovely spice note from the belgian yeast and a touch of red wine on the back end before the subtle, roasty finish. palate is medium bodied and highly carbonated giving this one a creamy texture on the palate. overall, another finely crafted beer from stillwater.

An interesting brew. Reminds me a lot of Boulevards Dark Truth, but with more oomph. Deep dark pour with a moderate mocha head. Nose offers chocolate and some estery fruit notes. Banana. Yeah. Chocolate with a hint of banana. Medium-to-heavy mouthfeel, plenty of carbonation, lively on the tongue. Palate offers an interesting combination of bitter coffee, roast, with mild smokiness and fruityness in the background. Finishes mildly bitter.  Its pretty decent, but I dont really know if I feel like wasting the daily ration on this one.

Two years in a row at the Fest, Stillwater had the best beer. I see the style was changed to stout. That makes sense, the esters were used to benefit, but they took a back seat to the sublimely roasted male. A touch of smoke brings a smile as you sip this dark pour.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2011 25 to 1 label.  This beer pours fairly black and is tan and translucent around the edges.  The head is small and tan.  Both the nose and flavor of this beer are more reminiscent of a porter or even a smoked beer than a stout.  Smokey, malty, slightly sweet, this is a solid offering.  Stillwater can brew a good beer.

500 ml bottle. Pours a totally black hue with a medium light brown head. A sweet nose of cocoa, light smoke, caramel and ash. The flavor is very nice; sweet milky chocolate, certainly some Belgian banana esters, fruity, light char, easygoing. A nice brew.
Bottle generously shared at the RBSG grand tasting. Pours a dark chocolate brown. Aroma has boatloads of coffee, as does the flavor. Slightly yeasty quality. Thin body with a coffee-nutty finish.
Brown black pour with tan head and lace. Light chocolate, no coffee, and toasted malt. Sweet chocolate malt with, some abv, and a hinto sour. A bit thin and watery to me.

500ml bottle from State Line. For some reason I was not expecting this to be a foreign stout (no doubt because of Stillwaters previous efforts, squarely in the farmhouse). It was certainly an interesting one, with a deep, vigorously carbonated cola-pour. There was a bit of Belgian yeast and moderate funk in the nose, with hints of fruitbread and mild char. Mouthfeel was nicely full, with the carbonation not at all interfering with a silky body. Far fewer dry roasty flavors than expected but thats fine by me, and it came across to me like a hybrid of a black saison and a Belgian stout. Yum.
A nice foreign stout that has all the characteristics of a stillwater beer.  Aroma of light sweetness roast and cola.  Taste is lightly fruity and smokey with a thin palate.
Tasty Belgian yeasts really taste like a Belgian stout, light and fruity yet roasted and dark malty. Excellent stout.
Bottle shared by willblake at RBSG.  Thanks Jon!  Notes of roast, brett, some light tartness, cherry skins, smoke.  Pretty tasty and interesting.

Bottle, thanks to Willblake. Pours out a dark brown with a moderate off white head. Aroma is of dried fruits, light chocolate and some roast. Taste is complex, light roast, some burnt wood, slight chocolate and some light fruity notes hanging in there also. Lots going on in this one.

Dark brown color with a small, light tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of cocoa, spices, some phenols, light roast, and some burnt wood. Taste of caramel, roast, burnt chestnuts, spices, and a smoky finish.

500 ML Bottle-Dark pour w/no head. Chocolate/yeasty aroma. Flavors of chocolate, some coffee, yeast, bread dough, grain. Very smooth & easy to drink, alcohol is well hidden. Another winner from these folks!

So very rich, I had to explain to my friend how a stout, foreign stout, and imperial stout are different.  It is hard when you dont use descxriptions that reference those beers themselves.  This was satisfying: chocolate and toasty warmth, but relatively mild hop influence (it is so nice getting stouts on the East Coast since they know what not to do with hops in a stout.  Lovely palate.  (on tap, Rattle N Hum, NYC).

Dark brown black pour beige head light sticky lacing ..... Aroma of chocolate, dark fruity yeast and roasted malts ..... Taste is of bitter dark chocolate and roasted malts, dark fruity yeast, little bit of licorice .... Smooth and oily mouthfeel with a dry lingering roasted finish .... Very smooth and delicious brew abv hidden well

This poured a adrker brown color with a light tan head. Aroma was very nice medium roast coffee and some black licorice as well. Flavor was much more licorice than coffee, some darker chocolate and roasted malts as well, nice stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2011 Had this at teh RB Pgh Tasting @ lithys, 5/21/11.  Big thanks to MrChopin forthis one!  Big black pour from a bottle, musty old wet burned wood aromas. Large bold taste of old wet charred wood that was soaking in pond water. Not as over top as I was expecting. There is alky in there but you would not know it was close to 9%.  Its not in your face like so many foreign stouts. Much better than lion stout. Finish is OK but it does border on imp stout territory. retreat to act like a dry stout of sorts on the finish. Thanks Kevin for a chance to try this beer!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Dark brown, light brown red edges.  Light tan foam.  Aroma is dry roastiness.  Taste is some choc, very roasty, nice dry finish.

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours an almost impenetrable black with a small but well sustained tan head.  The nose has a lot going on with dark fruit notes (plum and cherry), smoke and roasted malt.  The flavor starts off dark and almost creamy but with enough carbonation to lighten things up.  Nice roasted malt, cocoa powder, cherry, and prune notes come out.  They are overtaken by a harsh metallic note which then fades to a peaty smokiness leaving you with a bit of cocoa and earth in a surprisingly dry finish.  Medium to rich in body with higher levels of mostly smooth carbonation leading to a medium to long, dry finish.  Interesting and complex but there are some odd angles in this brew.

Bottle thanks to ryan.
Brown colored brew with some off-white head.  Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, and some fruitiness.  Tastes of estery yeast, milk chocolate, and roasted malt.
Draft at rattle with Linh, streets and goldylocks. Pours deep brown body with thin white lacing. Aroma is sweet roast and smoke. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of roast, meat, and smoke.

Pours black, brown at edges, long lasting slight head, quite compact, could almost pass as nitrod.  Aroma is mildly chocolate.  Flavor is complex - chocolate, a hint of coffee, and then a really nice fruity finish that borders on tropical.  Estery and not at all phenolic.  Realy enjoyed this one, very well done.  Great mouthfeel too, light touch on the carbonation.

Thanks to Holdwine.;  Although changed to stout category I think this beer could fall into the belgian strong ale category, somewhere in between a triple, quad and stout.  To me the belgian yeast comes through with a dark fruit, yeasty, bready and slightly sour character. very belgian.  The malt character is also there, with undertones of chocolate, coffee and smoke.  Whatever the category its a fine beer to be coming out of the BWI area and a new brewer.  Great balance, complex flavors, good stuff.

The aroma is chocolate, cream, roast, coffee, some fruit.  The appearance is deep black, light tan head.  The flavor is coffee, smoke, licorice, fruit.  The finish is sweet cream, and after a few seconds, pine hop bittering.  Medium/thick to thick in body.  Nice stout.
Tap. Light khaki head and nearly black dark brown hue. Plumy, fruity, and a light roast in the aroma.  Cocoa, slightly bitter coffee, plums, and a bit of roast.  Softer body and carbonation.

500mL bottle courtesy of Sloth. THis is the best of its style Ive had to date. Pours a deep cloudy black with a lovely thick tan head. Sweet chocolate and malt aroma, with fruitiness from the yeast. Roasted flavor, light sweetness, a bit of dark fruit/ Finishes full  with a hint of smokiness.

Pours deep dark brown with slight tan head that quickly dissipated.  Aroma is roasty, coffee and nutty.  Taste is sweet with bitter coffee finish.  Very refreshing stout on a nice day at Hawthornes with Chalsk

(500ml bottle, courtesy of Ryan)  Pours a murky brown body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, prunes, raisins, chocolate, and yeast.  Flavor of roasted malt, Belgian yeast, raisins, dates, subtle smoke, and chocolate with a dry finish.

Bottle shared with Leafs93 at Hawthornes.  Pours a black color with a caramel colored head.  Has a nice roasty aroma with hints of smoke and vanilla.  Has a sweet smokey, roasty taste with a nice bitter layer.  The kicker is the hidden hit of dark fruit that kicks up through the finish.  Nice mouthfeel.  Just excellent.  Damn good beer.
Bottle. Cocoa and coffee aroma. Black low head. Quite roasted coffee and cocoa like notes, good hop balance, pleasant moreish  profile. Sparkly mouthfeel, good chewyness. Well crafted.

500 mL bottle in a snifter.  Was expecting an ale, but it was definitely a stout.  Glad to find out it actually is a stout.  Dark brown pour with minimal tan head.  Rich roasty aroma with hints of cocoa.  Malty coffee flavor with chocolate and minor hop flavor.  Excellent collaboration ale.

Picked up this bottle at Whole Foods in DC. Served in a Bruery tulip.

Pour yields a nearly-black brew with a good off-white head. Nice creamy head that sticks around for a bit before falling down and leaving a bit of lacing behind. The nose brings forward quite a bit of roasted malt along with a slight amount of dark fruits and a bit of light, earthy hops. The flavor is fairly similar. Theres a roast component up front along with some dark fruits and a bit of earth and spice from the yeast. Feel is light to medium with good carbonation and a nice bite. Drinks pretty well; a nicely-done brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-08-2011

500ml bottle. Poured a black color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of roast, smoke, tobacco, fruity, licorice, and chocolate. Tastes of roast, woodiness, spicy, some earthiness, and some dark fruits.

Bottle. Black bodied with a tall, fizzy beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, light cocoa, and hints of coffee. Taste is roasted malt, sour milk, dark, bittersweet chocolate, coffee beans, and yeast notes. Body is medium with a strong carbonation and a lingering acidic tartness. Mild dryness as well. Ends with more roasted malt, sour milk, cocoa, dark chocolate, yeast, faint fruit, and coffee notes.

5th March 2011  ACBF.  Opaque black beer, little tan head. Lactose dark malt nose. Light palate and for once not too dry! Lactose sweetish licorice with dark malt. Trace of chocolate. Dry finish. Not bad.

Tan head, clear deep deep brown with reddish notes, no retention whatsoever.. Aroma, fruity, belgian notes, a light spice, roasty, some choc, some coffee, very very complex... Flavor, fruity, smoky, roasty, complex, very light choc, big flavors, complex... medium full bodied slightly warming very smooth body... amazingly complex very flavorful beer, this was awesome..

Bottle picked up at StateLine. Poured into a snifter. Black in color, decent head that faded quickly. Aroma of some light roasted malts, coffee.. Taste is close to the nose... light roasted malts, coffee backbone... Light fruity taste in the back ground.... Simple but good... Texture is medium carbonation ... Overall: Nice beer

500 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Cola-like dark brown pour with a foamy khaki head.  Aroma of roasted malts, mild coffee, and light floral hops.  The flavor is smoky upfront followed by expected dark chocolate and dark roasted espresso and ends with a clean hop finish.  The malt flavors are assertive yet not overpowering or harsh.  The brewer gets this one just right.

Bottle.  Pours a bruin body with a tan off white head.  Dusty floral tones, spices, musky .  Dark roasted malt.   Bitter sweet chocolate tones, caramel and a hints of licorice.  Mild belgian spices and a hint of birch.  Prickly carbonation with a mild finish.  Very nice.

Squat bottle from Capones.  Pours hazy black with sticky tan head.  Nose is b;ack patent malt, cacao, chocolate, hops, mild roasty amnd rauchy notes.  Tastes rich, velvety, complex on the palate, with hops in the finish, and roasty chocolate malt, spicy blackberry esters, and some oaty lactic notes in the forefront.  Nice.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a medium, frothy and creamy tan head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma and flavor are heavy malt (roast, chocolate, coffee, nutty), medium hops (earthy) with fruity esters, smoke, prunes, and licorice.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation with a sweet finish.

On tap at RnH. Pour is dark brown to almost black with a thinner off-white head. Aroma is very malty and sweet with just a touch of hops in the background. Chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, toast. Flavor is roasty and sweet with a fairly dry finish. Medium bodied and pretty smooth.

500ml bottle poured into a tulip glass.  This beer smells of roasted malts and fruity yeasts.  A very interesting combo.  The beer is black with a dark brown one finger head.  The taste is roasted malts and coffee notes with some fruitiness from the Belgian yeasts coming through.  Definitely get notes of coffee and chocolate, but the yeasts make it different than a traditional Stout.  Palate is medium to heavy body with average carbonation.  Overall, this is one fantastic beer from two greats.  Never disappointed with Stillwater offerings, and this keeps that expectation high.

(Sample Date: 3/19/2011   Source:beerand blues2)   Roasty with lots of chocolate. Black with small tan head. Nice complexity of chocolate and roast with some earthy floral hop notes underneath. Medium body and mouth feel. Finish is dry and roasty with just a tad of roasty astringency with a bit of warming lingering. Tasty.
Sampled at the Richmond 14th Gathering.  This is TOTALLY not a belgian strong ale.  It is a stout.  And a damn good one at that. Complex and belgian yeasty.  Nicely done.

Bottle 500ml. @ Th. 4th. Alvinne Craft Beer Festival (ACBF) 2011, De Kasteelhoeve, Doorniksesteenweg 314, Outrijve (Avelgem), Belgium.Clear medium to dark brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, dark chocolate. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, belgium yeast. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110304]

Bottle @ ACBF 2011. A black colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of some mocha with dark fruits like raisins with notes of coffee bitter. The taste of dark fruits like pune with raisins. Some mocha and coffee. The aftertaste is bitter with notes of sweet.
Pour is dark for a Belgian strong. Has some chocolate character with some fruity smell as well. Taste has similar characteristics but is more complex.

Bottles shared at the 5,000 party. Poured a great dark black body with an average sized foamy beige head. Aroma of dark chocoalte, yeast, a touch sour, tobacco. Flavor of slightly sour chocolate, yeast, brown toast, tobacco, soy and fruity hops. Thinner to average body with average carbonation. Very nice and seemed more like a Beligan stout then a BSA since it was so dark and roasty.

Tap at Paradiso Dupont. Pours fairly black, mostly deep cola red, with a dark brown, mocha head. Aroma is powerful cocoa nibs- can smell this before it is even in my hand. Heavy cerise noire, Taste is sharp and powerfully bitter. Heavy roast and raspberry dark chocolate abound along with liquored dark chocolate truffles and black cherries. Booziness is present, but soft and welcome. Very nice. Pretty much a well made fruity Belgian stout. Palate goes a tad carboardy but is lightly oily, full bodied, and finishes bitter.

Little beige to greige head, gone in secs over black beer. Inky, coffee, chocolate, preserved prunes, chocolatecake and toffee - a rich nose, otherways said. Smoky, ashes, dry stale coffee. Faint cakey sweetness and lots of bitterish roast in the throat. Retronasal some shy esters.Warming up, more coffee and especially more alcohol.  Medium to well-bodied, grist slickness but also something pulvery. Nice - if not very Belgian in my book.  Thanks, MikeK!

Bottle at ACBF 2011. Brown coloured. LIght brown head. ARoma of sweetness, chocolate, yeast, spice and ripe fruits. Flavour is light smoked, fruity, light roasted and has some yeast and spice in it. Medium bodied. Is sweet roasted and chocolaty in the end with a vague touch of smoke.
Bottle at ACBF 2011. Almost black - brown head. Licorice, coffee, fruity, herbal, light phenols, yeasty notes, caramel, roasted, dark malts, light bread, high malty, light berries. OK.

Bottle at ACBF 2011.
Dark brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Roasted aroma of caramel and dark chocolate with notes of yeast.
Sweet and roasted flavour of caramel, dark chocolate and yeast.
Roasted finish.

Bottle at the double 5k tasting.  Pours a hazed brown to black with a thin beige head.  Big roasty toast on the nose.  Chocolate, roast, lots of dark malts.  Chewy roast components.  Big yeast finish.  Nice.

On tap at Pizzeria Paradiso, Dupont: Pours a mostly opaque dark mahogany with a creamy froth of clingy-lacing beige head.  Has a lightly sweet dark caramel and biscuity malty nose with some light cocoa character and yeasty esters.  Starts with good fullness and finely-dissolved carbonation with a light nutty and dark malty sweetness with some dark chocolate and bready yeastiness before a smooth and balanced finish.  Very drinkable with decent complexity.

75 cL bottle at ACBF2011. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted dark malty, slight caramelish and light breadish. Sweet, roasted malty and slight breadish flavoured. Bitter and dark roasted malty. Ends dry and malty.

dark brown, lingering beige ring for a head. More robust malt, earth, bit smokey even compared to cocoa. Not as much chocolate but still enough. Anise and chocolate flavor, very light heat in the back, bit of sugary sweetness. Very nice anise-chocolate interplay, sugars helping.
Enjoyed on tap at Rattle N Hum.  Big chocolate, like an imperial stout.  Rich taste, sherry.  ABove average mouthfeel an drinkability.
stillwaterupours a jet black color with a light brown head. Smells of coffee and a bit of sugar. Taste is coffeey and delicious. Has a slightly bitter, dry taste. Not too shabby

500mL bottle.  An opaque black pour with a smallish mocha head.  Roasted coffee, dark chocolate, molasses, anise, plums, caramel, vanilla extract, raisins, and an estery dark fruit quality in the aroma.  Medium to full-bodied and smooth on the way down.  A little caramel upfront in the taste along with some touches of molasses, anise, vanilla extract, and raisins.  Some bittering dark chocolate, cocoa, and plenty of roasted coffee at the end.  A unique grainy yeastiness throughout.  The 8.4% ABV is pretty well-hidden.  Not bad at all.

Bottle shared at Paul and Ryans 5,000th rate tasting. Pours dark brown with an off white head. Belgian yeasty aroma with lightly roasted malts and clove. The flavor has roasted malts, belgian yeasty spicey notes, and a light hint of smoke. Delicious.

Draft. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is cocoa, vanilla, coffee, belgo yeast. Flavor is roasty, rich chocolate, vanilla, and oak with a malty finish. Closer to a belgo or foreign stout than a belgian strong ale.
Tap at rnh. Smells of raisins, cholate and coicoa. Taste is. The same with coffee and carmel beans. Very complex and interesting. Im enjoying this very much
Cask at Churchkey. Poured a dark brown color, medium sized tan/brown head. Aroma cocoa nibs notes, spices. Flavor roasted malts, chocolate, and caramel notes.

Bottle shared by someone at Paul and Ryans 5000th celebration, thanks! Poured a cloudy brown with a white head that slowly dissipated to the edges. Aroma had notes of dark grains and a bit of roast with some underlying light fruit and floral notes. Flavor began with dark grains, roast and a hint of smoke. The finish was a bit lighter with some light fruit and floral notes. An odd but interesting beer.
Bottle at Pauls and Ryans 5000th beer tasting. Pours dark brown. Nose of light smoke, chocolate malt and vanilla. Taste is lightly smoked chocolate malt, oak and vanilla. Smooth.

Draft at Maxs.  Dark brown pour with a light tan head.  Chocolate not as intense on the cask with chocolate nibs.  It is noticeable on top of a light roast nose.  Light sweetness with a bitter finish.

Draft, Maxs Belgian Fest 2011.  Small tan head atop cola black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, caramel, light vinous, alcohol.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, caramel, some coffee, earthy, light vinous.  Medium-full body, some stickiness.

Cask at Churchkey.  Very dark murky brown, massive brown head, solid lacing.  Aroma of cocoa and light spice.  taste smooth milk chocolate and cocoa powder.  Incredible stuff, nice balance and complexity.  Could not believe that this is a 10% beer.
This was my favorite cask tasting at the festival. Great fruity taste and a nice complex aroma. This one had a nice consistent head where as the cocoa nibs version did not b/c of the cocoa.

Big milk chocolate nose, its more of a sweet note than the cocoa nibs version was, Im guessing this has carafa in it. Light to moderate sweetness, more milk chocolate, light roast, some coffee and dark fruits, a touch of cola and some fruity yeast. Great beer, a fitting tribute to both!
